profileText: a Delegate from Delaware; born in Philadelphia, Pa., in 1747; graduated from Princeton College in 1771; served in the Revolutionary War; studied law in Philadelphia; was admitted to the Delaware bar in 1779 and commenced practice in Dover, Del.; moved to Wilmington, Del.; Member of the Confederation Congress, 1783-1785; appointed attorney general of Delaware on April 26, 1784, and served until September 26, 1789; appointed a commissioner to the convention held at Annapolis, Md., in September 1786 but did not attend; member of the Federal Constitutional Convention at Philadelphia in 1787; signer of the U.S. Constitution; delegate to the Delaware state convention that ratified the Federal Constitution in 1787; member of the Delaware state senate in 1788; appointed United States judge for the district of Delaware, September 26, 1789, which position he held until his death in Wilmington, Del., March 30, 1812; interment in First Presbyterian Churchyard, Wilmington, Del.; reinterred at the Masonic Home of Delaware, on Lancaster Pike, two miles west of Wilmington, Del.; reinterred in Wilmington and Brandywine Cemetery, Wilmington, Del.
